comments.text: Another interesting bit of translation (this one in P4A/P4AU). Aigis describes Yūki by using the term "taisetsu na hito" (大切な人), the same term used by Junpei to describe Chidori— "beloved". In the english localization, they however go with the much more neutral "precious person"/"important person", which is much more similar to daiji na hito (大事な人) than taisetsu na. Could very well be a translation error since the two terms translate to the same thing (however are used very differently) and use similar kanji's
comments.author: @kor7700

comments.text: Mitsuru multilingual queen. But also I kinda like the French choice, since P3 seems to have that wierd connection to the language. The map in the original seems to have French text on it, and the lyrics in original Changing Seasons is just French figures of speech. Also it just reminds me of Clair de Lune - Light of the Moon by Debussy.
comments.author: @makokitsune6487

comments.text: Hmm, interesting

comments.text: If that was the intention mandarin or German would have suited better
comments.author: @Ananomally

comments.text:
To be fair, this isn't a flaw.
The idea is to make her speak in a language different to the one in the whole game. And of course, in Japanese it makes sense that she speaks English given how dominant English was in the corporate sphere back when the game first got released. But of course you can't get her to speak English in a fully English game because the message gets lost. So what would it be the option here? French. Doesn't help that she's an expert fencer.
At most, in the remake they could have made her speak Mandarin Chinese given how China is now the leading economic superpower.
comments.author: @LeonDVineNabura

comments.text: The French is hotter
comments.author: @gitosha

comments.text: Honestly, I think Latin would’ve been much better.
